item.title: Can java delete directories?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:18, topic:501805”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=620033.msg4254504#msg4254504 date=1362514115]
They do (what you said wasn’t my point though).

If you weren’t aware when it comes to Computing we tend to scale up our technology, what I mean by this is. We’ve made our processing speeds faster, our HDD sizes bigger and so on but as a whole we haven’t made things a whole lot smaller (not physically I meant something like the CPU requirements etc - games are a good example [go on Steam and look at requirements for a game series go up and up the more recent the game is]) i.e. Compare your current PC/laptop to your previous one specs wise, the latest PC/laptop is better right? If I compared your power units it should consume more power.
I know how SATA and SSD HDDs work, they both would require more energy the higher the storage capacity they require (assuming the software is left the same and the technology is of the same standard).
[/quote]

You’re also disregarding the significant advancements in modern hardware to mitigate the high energy problem, such as turning off devices or partially turning them off to lower power usage.[/quote]
Feel free to look up statistics of power consumption statistics, I’ve seen the numbers (estimates of course) myself about a year ago. They’ve increased a lot and are expected to increase even more.

imthenull:

Just because you have a better processor/hard drive/etc doesn’t mean you sacrifice energy efficiency.

I never said it did, I said as long as the software and hardware is suitably scaled power consumption would rise. If you were use more effective software/hardware then that would be different.

Edit: Tahorak I forgot to state I wasn’t disregarding the advancements read what I said carefully next time & ofc I didn’t want to state the whole point.

Read full topic

item.title: Can java delete directories?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

imthenull:

digital waste… Lol’d irl

N why’s that?:o
I took this paragraph out of a report I did for one of my assessments and I have modified it slightly so it makes a bit more sense in this context (the wordings going to get messed up since I’m removing words and adding to the sentence a-pose to re-structuring the sentence but y’all should be used to me doing that).

One of the main issues with Computing is that a lot of electricity is required which can create high Co2 emissions as their are millions of computers running as we speak. On a personal level I have noticed people tend to bump up storage capacities rather than get rid of files such as installations for program-mes unless they are Computer savvy (personally I have a 1 TB HDD and a 1TB external HDD and I only use up to 400GB of storage where as my mother uses over 5TB on random movies/data). Co2 emissions can be reduced if renewable energy is used, in the article it is stated that Strato reduced their co2 emissions by using renewable energy which shows that there is a benefit of using renewable energy.
I just left the end bit in so you could understand what I'm getting at. It wastes power (large scale it adds up) & money.

Read full topic

item.title: Can java delete directories?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:9, topic:501805”][quote author=Arcik link=topic=620033.msg4254071#msg4254071 date=1362480247]
Why do you care about the disk space on somebody else’s computer?

[/quote]
Cause I’m not an asshole. Why take up 2-3x the space for my cache on their computer?[/quote]

Well it’s not ‘your’ code, and it was released a very long time ago.

You can try something like this to rename the file;

[code] public void rename(File file) {
File old = new File(“oldcache”);
File newName = new File(“newcache”);

	if (old.isDirectory()) {  
		old.renameTo(newName);  
    } else {  
        file.mkdir();  
        old.renameTo(newName);  
    }
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Can java delete directories?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

What is the problem you’re having? A File is basically just an abstract representation of an inode, it can point to an actual file, or to a directory.

From the JavaDocs:

public boolean delete() Deletes the file or directory denoted by this abstract pathname. If this pathname denotes a directory, then the directory must be empty in order to be deleted.
So you'll want to use recursion to empty it.

void delete(File root) { for(File f : root.listFiles()) { if(f.isDirectory()) delete(f); else f.delete(); } }

Edit: Should also point out NIO.2 has a FileVisitor interface you can implement to easily walk a path and delete everything as needed.

Read full topic

item.title: Can java delete directories?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

I know it’s completely possible for java to delete a file or archive. But can you write code for it to delete an entire folder and the contents in it?

Yes, I know this section is for non-private server talk. But this is more of a question on java’s capabilities.

I wrote this for my client’s cache downloader:

	public  void deleteZip(){	
			try{
				drawLoadingText("Deleting Download File");
				File file = new File(getCacheDir()+"/MyZipNameHEre.zip");
	 
				if(file.delete()){
					System.out.println(file.getName() + " Zip Deleted");
					drawLoadingText("Download File Deleted");
				}else{
					System.out.println("Deletion Failed.");
				}
	 
			}catch(Exception e){
	 
				e.printStackTrace();
	 
			}
	 
		}

It’s rather self explanatory…
It deletes the .zip out of the directory. I did this to free space on the players computers, as it would keep the .zip in the directory with the extracted folders, taking up almost twice them hard drive space (it’s compressed and all).
But say I wanted to change the name of my cache, and the users didn’t know how to delete the old cache, so that’d be taking up literally 2x the space.

INB4 someone says I’m writing a program to delete system files or etc.

Read full topic
